It is susceptible to fractures when a person falls on an outstretched hand because of its position and the forces transmitted through the wrist during such an impact. Scaphoid fractures are common and can cause pain, tenderness, swelling, and limited wrist motion. It is important to diagnose and treat scaphoid fractures promptly, as they have a higher risk of complications such as nonunion (failure of the bone to heal) or avascular necrosis (loss of blood supply to the bone).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pisiform: The pisiform bone is a small bone located on the ulnar side of the wrist, anterior to the triquetrum bone. While fractures of the pisiform bone can occur, they are less common than scaphoid fractures after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Option C - Lunate: The lunate bone is located in the center of the proximal row of carpal bones. Although it can be involved in wrist injuries, fractures of the lunate bone are less common than scaphoid fractures in cases of a fall on an outstretched hand.

Option D - Hamate: The hamate bone is located on the ulnar side of the wrist, distal to the pisiform bone. While fractures of the hamate bone can occur, they are less common than scaphoid fractures after a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: Which of the following options is not linked to Sprengel deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Dextrocardia:

  • (Not associated) Dextrocardia refers to a condition in which the heart is situated on the right side of the chest instead of the left. While dextrocardia is a distinct condition, it is not typically associated with Sprengel deformity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diastematomyelia: (Associated) Diastematomyelia refers to a condition in which the spinal cord is split into two parts (bifid) by a bony or fibrous spur. Diastematomyelia has been reported in association with Sprengel deformity, suggesting a potential link between the two conditions.

Option B - Klippel-Feil syndrome: (Associated) Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae in the neck. It is commonly associated with Sprengel deformity, among other skeletal anomalies

Option D - Congenital scoliosis: (Associated) Congenital scoliosis is a spinal deformity that is present at birth and results from abnormal vertebral development. It has been reported in association with Sprengel deformity, suggesting a potential relationship between the two conditions.

questions.text: The following images A and B show?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Jersey finger & baseball finger:

  • Jersey finger & baseball finger: Jersey finger is a condition where the flexor tendon is torn or avulsed from its insertion at the DIP joint, usually resulting from forcefully extending the finger while it is flexed.
  • Baseball finger, also known as a mallet fracture, involves a fracture at the DIP joint caused by a sudden forceful impact to the tip of an extended finger.
  • Image A represents jersey finger, and image B represents baseball finger.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mallet finger & Jersey finger:

  • Mallet finger refers to a condition where the extensor tendon is torn at the DIP joint, leading to the inability to extend the finger fully.

Option B - Boxer fracture & march fracture:

  • Boxer fracture typically refers to a fracture of the metacarpal bone in the hand, specifically the neck of the metacarpal, usually resulting from a punch or direct trauma. March fracture refers to a stress fracture of the metatarsal bones in the foot.

Option C - Mallet finger & boxer fracture:

  • Mallet finger involves a tear or avulsion of the extensor tendon at the DIP joint, causing the inability to extend the finger fully. Boxer fracture refers to a fracture of the metacarpal bone in the hand.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the condition known as "painful arc syndrome"?

choices.text: A condition in which joint stiffness lasts for more than 30 minutes in the morning, affecting multiple joints.
A condition characterized by localized, sharp pain at the site of an injury or inflammation.
A condition where pain is experienced during a specific range of motion, typically between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction.
A condition marked by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas of the body.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A condition where pain is experienced during a specific range of motion, typically between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction:

  •  Painful arc syndrome, also known as "subacromial impingement," is characterized by pain during a specific range of motion, usually between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction. This condition often occurs due to compression or impingement of structures in the subacromial space, such as the rotator cuff tendons, as the arm is raised.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A condition in which joint stiffness lasts for more than 30 minutes in the morning, affecting multiple joints:

  • This option does not accurately describe "painful arc syndrome." Joint stiffness in the morning for more than 30 minutes is typically associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, not painful arc syndrome.

Option B - A condition characterized by localized, sharp pain at the site of an injury or inflammation:

  • This option describes localized pain at the site of an injury or inflammation, which can be associated with various musculoskeletal or traumatic conditions but is not specific to painful arc syndrome.

Option D - A condition marked by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas of the body:

  • This option describes fibromyalgia, a condition characterized by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas of the body. It is a different condition unrelated to painful arc syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures is most prone to non-union?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  A - Proximal Scaphoid:

  • The scaphoid bone is located in the wrist, and fractures in the proximal portion (near the base) of the scaphoid are notorious for their high risk of non-union. Non-union refers to the failure of a fracture to heal properly, resulting in persistent pain, limited function, and potential complications. The blood supply to the proximal scaphoid is relatively poor, making it susceptible to delayed or inadequate healing.

Incorrect Options:

Option  B - Inter-Trochanteric:

  • Inter-trochanteric fractures refer to fractures of the femur in the region between the greater and lesser trochanters. These fractures generally have a better healing potential compared to proximal scaphoid fractures.

Option  C - Distal Radius:

  • Distal radius fractures are common fractures of the forearm near the wrist. While they can be challenging, with appropriate treatment, they usually have a good prognosis and a lower risk of non-union compared to proximal scaphoid fractures.

Option  D - Talar Neck:

  • Talar neck fractures involve the neck of the talus bone in the foot. These fractures can be complex and have various degrees of blood supply compromise. While they carry a risk of complications, including non-union, the proximal scaphoid fracture is generally considered to be at a higher risk of non-union.

questions.text: The diagnosis of the given image
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Scapho Lunate Instability:

  •  Scapholunate instability: Scapholunate instability refers to an abnormal movement or separation of the scaphoid and lunate bones, which are two of the carpal bones in the wrist. This instability can be caused by injury or ligamentous damage, leading to improper alignment and movement of these bones. Based on the given image, if there are specific features or signs indicating scapholunate instability, this would be the correct option
  • Mechanism of Injury- Fall on an outstretched hand- Repetitive wrist trauma or overuse
  • Clinical Presentation; Wrist pain or tenderness
    • Swelling or instability in the wrist
    • Signs of chronic instability may include a "dinner fork" deformity or widening of the scapholunate joint
  • Physical Examination
    • Scaphoid shift test: Palpable "clunk" or abnormal movement of the scaphoid bone with ulnar deviation and wrist flexion
    • Watson test: Painful clunk or subluxation of the scaphoid during radial or ulnar deviation of the wrist
    • Terry Thomas sign: Increased scapholunate space on radiographic imaging, indicating abnormal alignment between the scaphoid and lunate bones
  • Radiographic Evaluation
    • X-rays: Routine radiographs may reveal widening of the scapholunate joint space (>3mm) on a lateral view (Terry Thomas sign)

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lunate Injury: This option suggests an injury specifically to the lunate bone in the wrist. While a lunate injury can occur, it is not the most accurate description based on the given information or image.

Option C - Distal Radioulnar Joint Instability: Distal radioulnar joint instability refers to instability of the joint between the radius and ulna bones in the forearm. It does not specifically relate to the diagnosis of lunate instability depicted in the image.

Option D - Wrist Dislocation: Wrist dislocation refers to a complete displacement of one or more of the carpal bones in relation to the other wrist bones. While it is possible to have a dislocation in the wrist, it may not be the most accurate interpretation based solely on the given image.

questions.text: Three point bony relationship has a diagnostic value in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Elbow Fracture:

  • The three-point bony relationship refers to the alignment of three specific landmarks in the elbow joint: the capitellum , the radial head , and the olecranon process. When these three points are aligned properly, it indicates that the elbow joint is in its normal anatomical position.
  • In the context of elbow fractures, assessing the three-point bony relationship is crucial in determining the presence of a fracture and evaluating its displacement or dislocation. Any disruption in the alignment of these three points may indicate a fracture or joint injury.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Monteggia Fracture: A Monteggia fracture is a specific type of forearm fracture-dislocation that involves a fracture of the ulna shaft and dislocation of the radial head. While it affects the elbow joint, the diagnostic evaluation of a Monteggia fracture is typically based on the fracture pattern and the dislocation of the radial head, rather than the three-point bony relationship.

Option C - Galeazzi Fracture: A Galeazzi fracture is another forearm fracture that involves a fracture of the radius shaft with associated dislocation or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ). Similar to the Monteggia fracture, the diagnostic evaluation of a Galeazzi fracture focuses on the fracture pattern and the DRUJ dislocation, rather than the three-point bony relationship.

Option D - Colles' Fracture: Colles' fracture is a type of distal radius fracture characterized by a fracture of the distal end of the radius, typically resulting from a fall onto an outstretched hand. The diagnosis of Colles' fracture is primarily based on the clinical presentation, physical examination findings, and radiographic evaluation, such as X-rays. The three-point bony relationship is not specifically utilized for diagnosing Colles' fracture.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child complaining of pain and swelling is suspected with supracondylar fracture of right hand (Undisplaced). X-ray of right elbow was not significant. What is the next best step in this case?

choices.text: Compare with X-ray of left hand
Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab (90 degree flexion)
Closed reduction with K wire fixation Cast

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab (90 degree flexion):

  • Supracondylar fractures of the humerus are common injuries in pediatric patients. These fractures occur just above the elbow joint and can result in pain, swelling, and deformity of the affected arm. The initial evaluation typically involves an X-ray of the elbow to assess the fracture.
  • In this case, if the X-ray of the right elbow is not significant(undisplaced),  Therefore, the next best step would be Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab(90 degree flexion).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Comparing with X-ray of the left hand: Comparing the X-ray of the right hand with the X-ray of the left hand may be helpful in certain situations to assess for any asymmetry or differences in bone structure. However, in the case of a suspected supracondylar fracture, comparing with the X-ray of the left hand alone may not provide sufficient information to confirm or manage the fracture.

Option C - Closed reduction with K wire fixation cast: This is done in Displaced fractures

Option D - Cast: Applying a cast alone without closed reduction may not be appropriate for managing a suspected supracondylar fracture.

questions.text: A Post-menopausal women slipped and fell down on an outstretched hand in the washroom.  X-ray of her distal forearm is given below. Diagnose the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Colle's Fracture:

  • Postmenopausal women are prone to develop osteoporosis due to decreased secretion of estrogen from ovaries. Women suffering from osteoporosis are prone to Colles fracture, which is a type of wrist fracture. This type of fracture usually happens after falling on an outstretched hand. The given x-ray shows fracture of the distal end of radius at cortico- cancellous junction, hence, Colles fracture is the correct choice.

Fracture Name

Characteristic Findings

Sites Involved

Special History

Colles' Fracture

Dorsal displacement of the distal radius

Distal radius

Falling on an outstretched hand

Smith's Fracture

Volar displacement of the distal radius

Distal radius

Falling on a flexed wrist

Monteggia Fracture

Proximal ulnar shaft fracture with radial head dislocation

Proximal ulna, radial head

Direct blow to the ulna or forearm

Galeazzi Fracture

Distal radial shaft fracture with distal radioulnar joint dislocation

Distal radius, radioulnar joint

Fall on an outstretched hand with an ulnar deviation

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Montaggiea fracture: The Monteggia fracture is the fracture of proximal ulna, which is associated with radial head dislocation. The given radiograph is indicating a distal radial fracture, hence it’s not a Monteggia fracture.

Option C - Smith Fracture: The image is not indication towards Smith fracture because volar angulation is the characteristic of Smith fracture, whereas the x-ray image is showing a dorsal angulation which is a characteristic of Colles fracture.

Option D - Galeazzi fracture: Galeazzi fracture, is the fracture of the middle of the distal third of the radius whereas the radiograph is showing a distal radial fracture hence it’s not the Galeazzi fracture.

questions.text:
Assertion: Proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis

Reason : Blood supply is retrograde from its distal to proximal end

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is correct not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Assertion is false, but the reason is true
Both assertion is and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Both the assertion and the reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

  •  The proximal pole of the scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis. This means that the blood supply to the proximal pole is compromised, leading to tissue death.
  •  The reason given is that the blood supply to the scaphoid bone is retrograde, meaning it flows from the distal end (near the wrist) towards the proximal end (closer to the forearm). This retrograde blood supply makes the proximal pole more vulnerable to avascular necrosis as it receives blood last.
  • The reason provided in the statement correctly explains why the proximal pole of the scaphoid is more prone to avascular necrosis. The retrograde blood supply pattern makes this region of the bone more susceptible to ischemia and subsequent necrosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - This option suggests that both the assertion and the reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: However, the reason is indeed the correct explanation for the assertion.

Option C - This option states that the assertion is true, but the reason is false: However, the reason is true and provides a valid explanation for the assertion.

Option D - This option suggests that the assertion is false, but the reason is true: However, the assertion is indeed true, as supported by the high incidence of avascular necrosis in the proximal pole of the scaphoid.

Option E - This option states that both the assertion and the reason are false: However, both the assertion and the reason are true and supported by clinical evidence.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct about anterior shoulder dislocation except :

choices.text: Recurrence rate is maximum if the patients age less than 20 years
Axillary nerve is most commonly injured
CT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion
Anterior shoulder dislocation is most common typeof shoulder dislocation,

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion:

  • CCT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion: This statement is incorrect.
  • While CT scans can provide detailed information about bony lesions in the shoulder, they are not typically the first-line imaging modality used for diagnosing anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • The primary method for diagnosing shoulder dislocation is a combination of clinical evaluation, physical examination, and X-ray imaging.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Recurrent rate is maximum if the patients age less than 20 years: This statement is correct. Anterior shoulder dislocation has a higher recurrence rate in patients younger than 20 years of age. This is due to the increased laxity of the joint structures and the higher likelihood of engaging in activities that can cause shoulder instability.

Option B - Axillary nerve is most commonly injured: This statement is correct. The axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle and the skin over the shoulder, is commonly injured in anterior shoulder dislocations. The nerve can be stretched, compressed, or damaged during the dislocation, leading to temporary or permanent weakness or sensory loss.

Option D - Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common type of shoulder dislocation: This statement is correct. Anterior shoulder dislocation is indeed the most common type of shoulder dislocation, accounting for the majority of all shoulder dislocations.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall on their outstretched hand. The X-ray image is given below. Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Scaphoid Fracture:

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the radial side of the wrist, and the scaphoid bone is one of the bones that forms its floor.
  • A fall on an outstretched hand can cause a scaphoid bone fracture, most common in young adults, particularly males, and is often the result of FOOSH injury with the wrist in extension.
  • Symptoms include tenderness and swelling in the anatomical snuffbox, pain with gripping or squeezing, and limited range of motion in the wrist.
  • It has a high risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis.
  • X-ray findings:
    • visualization of the fracture +/- displacement
    • soft tissue swelling and lateral displacement of the adjacent fat pads

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Colles Fracture: Colles fracture is a type of distal radius fracture where the distal fragment is displaced dorsally (backward). It occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hand with the wrist extended. The symptoms include pain, swelling, and deformity in the wrist.

Option C - Smith Fracture: It is a type of distal radius fracture where the distal fragment is displaced volarly (forwards). It occurs due to a fall on the back of the hand with the wrist flexed. 

Option D - Galeazzi Fracture: It is a fracture of the distal third of the radius associated with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. It occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hand with the forearm pronated (palm facing downwards). The symptoms include pain, swelling, and deformity in the wrist and forearm.
